title: How your muscular system works - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: How many muscles work together to perform a single step?
What are the three main types of muscles in the muscular system?
What is the primary function of the skeletal muscles in the muscular system?

options.label: C
options.text: To generate most of the body's motion

multiple-choice.question: What type of muscle contraction allows us to grip a mug of coffee or lean against a wall?
What percentage of the body's weight is made up of skeletal muscles?
What is the name of the muscle that attaches the cheek to the teeth?
What type of nervous system controls the skeletal muscles?
What is the primary function of fast-twitch muscle fibers?

options.label: B
options.text: To react quickly and generate instant force

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of times the heart beats in a person's lifetime?
What percentage of the body's warmth is provided by muscle activity?

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the deformity observed in the lambs born to sheep in Idaho in the 1950s?
What was the initial hypothesis of the researchers regarding the cause of the deformity in the sheep?
What was the name given to the active molecule found in the wild corn lilies that caused the deformity?
Who led the team of biologists that discovered the connection between cyclopamine and the hedgehog gene?
What is the function of the hedgehog gene in normal development?

options.label: C
options.text: To tell cells to release the hedgehog protein

multiple-choice.question: How does cyclopamine interrupt the normal development pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: By binding to the hedgehog protein

options.label: C
options.text: By binding to the smoothened protein

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein?
Why was cyclopamine not used as a treatment for cancers despite its potential?

options.label: D
options.text: It was not approved by the FDA

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the research on cyclopamine and its related molecules?

options.label: B
options.text: Two related molecules were approved as skin cancer medicines

options.label: C
options.text: Cyclopamine was approved as a treatment for cancers

multiple-choice.question: What is the main lesson from the story of the cyclops sheep?

options.label: A
options.text: That genetic mutations are always freak occurrences

options.label: B
options.text: That sometimes there's more than meets the eye

options.label: C
options.text: That scientists should never investigate unusual occurrences

options.label: D
options.text: That all deformities are caused by environmental factors

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: What did ancient people use to count objects before developing more complex number systems?
In Ancient Greece, who developed the study of numbers and found numerical patterns in shapes, music, and the stars?

What was the punishment for Hippasus, according to legends, for publicizing his findings on irrational numbers?
Which mathematical system, developed by other cultures, was introduced to Europe through Arab travelers in the Middle Ages?
Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals initially banned in Florence in the 13th century?

options.label: B
options.text: They were easier to forge or alter

options.label: C
options.text: They were too difficult to learn

options.label: D
options.text: They were not useful for merchants

Why are some numbers banned today, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: Because of what they represent or the information they carry

multiple-choice.question: What was the example given in the transcript of a number that was widely shared and distributed, and was considered a potential criminal offense?

options.label: A
options.text: A large prime number that could be used to decrypt DVDs

options.label: B
options.text: A code that could be used to hack into computers

options.label: C
options.text: A password that could be used to access protected information

options.label: D
options.text: A numerical representation of a copyrighted image

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why is the concept of "illegal numbers" not as absurd as it may seem?

options.label: A
options.text: Because numbers are just abstract concepts

options.label: B
options.text: Because numbers can be used to represent and convey information

options.label: C
options.text: Because numbers are only used in mathematics

options.label: D
options.text: Because numbers are not important in our daily lives

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of the rubber hand illusion experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the importance of physical sensations in our judgment of self.

options.label: B
options.text: To prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness.

options.label: C
options.text: To show how easily our senses can be misled.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the limits of human endurance.

multiple-choice.question: According to René Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?
What is the problem that arises if we accept the notion of a non-physical consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: How can a non-physical mind have any interaction with the physical body?

options.label: B
options.text: How can a physical body have any interaction with a non-physical mind?

options.label: C
options.text: How can we distinguish between a non-physical mind and a physical body?

options.label: D
options.text: How can we prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness?

multiple-choice.question: Who claimed that when we think about reaching for a fork, it's actually God who moves our hand?
What is the conclusion of many modern scientists regarding the mind-body problem?

options.label: A
options.text: The mind and body are two separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: The mind and body are deeply integrated and inseparable.

options.label: C
options.text: The mind is a product of the brain, but the body is not.

options.label: D
options.text: The body is a product of the mind, but the brain is not.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the role of our senses in forming our experience of self?

options.label: A
options.text: They create new maps and representations in the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: They regulate our emotions and feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: They distinguish between our physical and non-physical aspects.

options.label: D
options.text: They are irrelevant to our experience of self.

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea behind mind uploading?

options.label: A
options.text: Transferring a human consciousness into a computer to achieve immortal life.

options.label: B
options.text: Uploading our thoughts and memories into a computer to free up space in our brains.

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a virtual reality where we can exist without our physical bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: Developing neural prosthetics to enhance our cognitive abilities.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a possible requirement for mind uploading to be possible?

options.label: A
options.text: Simulating a body capable of delivering physical sensations.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a computer program that can mimic human emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing a neural network that can replicate human thought patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: Building a robot that can mimic human movements.

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher suggested that the material world is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions?
What is the open question that remains at the end of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the nature of consciousness?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the relationship between the mind and body?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the definition of self?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the meaning of life?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: 30% of test takers scored below her

What is the difference between an unreliable thermometer and a reliable but invalid thermometer?

options.label: A
options.text: An unreliable thermometer is consistently ten degrees too hot, while a reliable but invalid thermometer gives different readings each time

options.label: B
options.text: An unreliable thermometer gives different readings each time, while a reliable but invalid thermometer is consistently ten degrees too hot

options.label: C
options.text: An unreliable thermometer is consistently ten degrees too cold, while a reliable but invalid thermometer gives different readings each time

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because they're not motivated to do well

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The test may not be standardized

options.label: C
options.text: The test may have a validity problem

options.label: D
options.text: The test may not be normalized

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the responsibility of users of standardized tests?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What was Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, issued on January 1, 1863?
What is the process of passing laws in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The president proposes a bill, and Congress votes on it

options.label: B
options.text: A member of Congress proposes a bill, and the president signs it

options.label: C
options.text: A member of Congress proposes a bill, which is then approved by committees, revised, and voted on by Congress before being sent to the president for signature

options.label: D
options.text: The president issues an executive order, which becomes a law

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between an executive order and a law?

options.label: A
options.text: An executive order is passed by Congress, while a law is issued by the president

options.label: B
options.text: An executive order is enforced like a law, but it is not passed by Congress

options.label: C
options.text: An executive order is a temporary measure, while a law is permanent

options.label: D
options.text: An executive order is only used in times of crisis, while a law is used in all situations

multiple-choice.question: Who has the power to invalidate an executive order?
What can a president's successor do to an executive order issued by the previous president?
When do presidents often use executive orders?

options.label: C
options.text: To exert power without working with Congress, or to clarify and implement policies

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of FDR's executive order establishing the Works Progress Administration?

options.label: B
options.text: To build roads, bridges, and parks, and to employ artists and writers

options.label: C
options.text: To establish requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment

options.label: D
options.text: To intern Japanese-Americans during World War II

multiple-choice.question: Which president issued the most executive orders?
What can Congress do to counteract an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: Pass a law to amend it

options.label: B
options.text: Pass a law to counteract it

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the U.S. Constitution being ambiguous on the extent of the president's power?

options.label: C
options.text: Executive orders have expanded over time

options.label: D
options.text: The president's power has been reduced

title: What are gravitational waves? - Amber L. Stuver

multiple-choice.question: What event did scientists witness on September 14, 2015?

options.label: B
options.text: The collision of two black holes

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of a new planet

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the detector that picked up the signal from the collision of two black holes?
What are gravitational waves?

options.label: A
options.text: Ripples in space-time caused by changes in gravity

options.label: C
options.text: A type of particle that travels through space

options.label: D
options.text: A type of wave that only affects the Earth

multiple-choice.question: According to Einstein's Theory of Relativity, what is gravity?

options.label: A
options.text: A force that pulls objects apart

options.label: B
options.text: A curve in space-time caused by mass

options.label: C
options.text: A type of energy that travels through space

options.label: D
options.text: A type of particle that attracts other particles

multiple-choice.question: What would a gravitational wave feel like if our bodies were sensitive enough to detect them?

options.label: A
options.text: A constant stretching in one direction

options.label: B
options.text: A back-and-forth stretching and compressing in different directions

options.label: C
options.text: A vibration that only affects the ears

options.label: D
options.text: A sensation that only affects the eyes

multiple-choice.question: How do LIGO detectors work?

options.label: A
options.text: They use lasers to measure the length of their arms, which can be affected by gravitational waves

options.label: B
options.text: They use microphones to detect the sound of gravitational waves

options.label: C
options.text: They use telescopes to observe the effects of gravitational waves on distant objects

options.label: D
options.text: They use magnets to attract and detect gravitational waves

multiple-choice.question: What type of information can scientists extract from the signal detected by LIGO?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the mass of the objects that generated the gravitational wave

options.label: B
options.text: Only the shape of the orbit of the objects that generated the gravitational wave

options.label: C
options.text: Both the mass and the shape of the orbit of the objects that generated the gravitational wave

options.label: D
options.text: Neither the mass nor the shape of the orbit of the objects that generated the gravitational wave

multiple-choice.question: What is the "chirp" sound that scientists detected from the collision of two black holes?
What other types of events can produce gravitational waves that can be detected by LIGO?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the collision of two black holes

options.label: B
options.text: The collision of two black holes and the explosion of a supernova

options.label: C
options.text: The collision of two black holes, the explosion of a supernova, and the collision of two neutron stars

options.label: D
options.text: The collision of two black holes, the explosion of a supernova, the collision of two neutron stars, and the formation of a new star

multiple-choice.question: What has LIGO revealed about the universe that was not expected?

options.label: A
options.text: That black holes do not exist

options.label: B
options.text: That gravitational waves are not real

options.label: C
options.text: That black holes collide more often than expected

options.label: D
options.text: That the universe is not expanding

multiple-choice.question: Why did Psyche's father abandon her on a rocky crag?

options.label: B
options.text: She found out he was the god Cupid and accidentally burned him with hot oil.

options.label: C
options.text: She found out he was a mortal man and fell in love with him even more.

options.label: B

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Psyche and Cupid's daughter?

title: The left brain vs. right brain myth - Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the popular myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain has a right and left side.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain controls different body functions.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world.

multiple-choice.question: Which internal regions of the brain appear to be made from continuous tissue but are organized with left and right sides?

options.label: B
options.text: Striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem

multiple-choice.question: How do the left and right sides of the brain control movement?

options.label: A
options.text: The left side controls the motion of the left arm and leg.

options.label: B
options.text: The right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls the motion of the right arm and leg.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's right side controls the motion of the left arm and leg and vice versa.

multiple-choice.question: How does the visual system process information from each eye?

options.label: A
options.text: Each eye sends information to the same side of the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Each eye sends information to the opposite side of the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Both left visual fields are sent to the right side of the brain, and both right fields are sent to the left side.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain uses only one eye to make a complete image of the world.

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists think the brain's left-right structure may have evolved?

options.label: C
options.text: To give the survival advantage of quicker reflexes

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the risk of brain damage

multiple-choice.question: Who introduced the idea of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional right hemisphere?

options.label: C
options.text: They showed a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative.

multiple-choice.question: Which brain function is more localized to the left side of the brain?
What does the transcript suggest about individuals having dominant sides of the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It is supported by scientific evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a myth with no scientific basis.

options.label: C
options.text: It varies from person to person.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only true for certain cognitive functions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between logic and creativity in the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: They are localized to different sides of the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: They are intertwined and work together.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for certain cognitive functions.

options.label: B

options.text: It blocks the receptors for adenosine

options.text: It has no effect on adenosine

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To inhibit the release of brain-signaling molecules

options.label: D
options.text: To increase heart rate and blood pressure

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: So you can misinterpret the data

options.label: D

options.text: Absence of particles in the urine

options.label: C
options.text: Drinking large amounts of water and taking pain killers

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the medication potassium citrate in treating kidney stones?

options.label: A
options.text: To relax the muscles in the ureter

options.label: B
options.text: To dissolve the stones by creating a less acidic urine

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the non-invasive treatment that uses high-intensity pulses of focused ultrasonic energy to break up kidney stones?
What can help prevent the formation of kidney stones in individuals prone to them?

options.label: C
options.text: Drinking plenty of water and limiting foods high in oxalate

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of calcium in foods and beverages on the formation of kidney stones?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the risk of forming kidney stones

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the formation of kidney stones

options.label: C
options.text: It helps prevent the formation of kidney stones by binding to oxalate

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the size of kidney stones

title: How to squeeze electricity out of crystals - Ashwini Bharathula

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon allows sugar crystals to generate electricity when pressed?

options.label: B
options.text: Pierre Curie and his brother Jacques

multiple-choice.question: What was the first practical application of piezoelectricity?

options.label: B
options.text: Sonar instruments used to detect German submarines during World War I

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a piezoelectric material is subjected to mechanical stress?
What is the key factor that determines whether a material is piezoelectric?

options.label: B
options.text: Its atomic structure and electric charge distribution

multiple-choice.question: What is the building block of a crystalline material called?
Why do some crystalline materials possess piezoelectricity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their unit cells have a center of symmetry

options.label: B
options.text: Because their unit cells lack a center of symmetry

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are made of atoms or ions arranged in a random pattern

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The atoms shift and the dipoles cancel each other out

options.label: B
options.text: The atoms shift and the dipoles no longer cancel each other out

options.label: C
options.text: The atoms remain stationary and the dipoles cancel each other out

options.label: D
options.text: The atoms remain stationary and the dipoles no longer cancel each other out

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Powering electronic devices using thermal energy

options.label: D
options.text: Powering electronic devices using electromagnetic induction

title: The power of creative constraints - Brandon Rodriguez

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: They contaminated soil samples with foreign chemicals

options.text: Focusing on the goal rather than the constraints

options.label: D

options.text: Cleaning municipal water in polluted cities

options.label: B
options.text: The invention of the light bulb

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between constraints and creativity?

options.label: B
options.text: Constraints are the boundaries of creativity

options.label: C
options.text: Constraints are the foundation of creativity
